pButton.Name: Liberalism
pButton.popInfo: While the liberalism of Europe has some similarities to liberalism in the United States, you must understand that these philosophies are different. European liberalism is a nineteenth- and twentieth-century ideology supporting individualism, political freedom, constitutional government, and (in the nineteenth century) laissez-faire (or no government intervention in) economic policies.

pButton.Name: Conservatism
pButton.popInfo:
As with liberalism, European conservatism differs from a modern American understanding of this term. European conservatism is an ideology that stresses order and traditional values. This often included a monarchical or other absolutist form of government, even into the twentieth century.
The ancien régime or “old order” in French is often associated with European conservatism. This term refers to the French political and social system before the Revolution, which included the three estates (clergy, nobility, everyone else) under the authority of the king.

pButton.Name: Nationalism
pButton.popInfo: Nationalism is a 19th or 20th century ideology stressing the importance of national identity and the nation-state.

pButton.Name: Constitutionalism
pButton.popInfo: Constitutionalism is the idea that political authority rests in written law, not in the person of an absolute monarch. While seemingly natural to us in the United States, this was a radical idea in most of Europe until the 19th century.

pButton.Name: Absolutism
pButton.popInfo: Royal absolutism is a government in which all power is vested in the ruler. In the 19th and 20th centuries, socialist and fascist dictators also ruled as absolutists.

pButton.Name: Imperialism
pButton.popInfo: Imperialism is the policy of extending a nation’s authority by territorial acquisition or by the establishment of economic and political control over other nations or peoples.

pButton.Name: Fascism
pButton.popInfo: Fascism is a philosophy or system of government that advocates a dictatorship of the extreme right together with an ideology of belligerent nationalism.

pButton.Name: Capitalism
pButton.popInfo: Capitalism is an economic system characterized by freedom of the market with private and corporate ownership of the means of production and distribution that are operated for profit.

pButton.Name: Socialism
pButton.popInfo: Socialism is a 19th and 20th century ideology stressing cooperation, community, and public ownership of the means of production (factories, machines, tools, etc.).

pButton.Name: Communism
pButton.popInfo: Communism is a far left social system advocated by Karl Marx and others beginning in the nineteenth century. The 20th century was the most active for the growth of communism, and there are still communist nations today. According to Marx, a communist system would eliminate private property, have a classless society, and all property would be owned by the community or the state.
